leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.50] r 51.50 Security for costs (cf SCR Part 51, rule 16)

leg:heading.title: Security for costs (cf SCR Part 51, rule 16)

p.text: In special circumstances, the Court may order that such security as the Court thinks fit be given for costs of an appeal.
Subject to subrules (1) and (3), no security for costs of an appeal is to be required.
Subrules (1) and (2) do not affect the powers of the Court under rule 42.21 (which relates to security for costs).

level.toc-caption: [51.50.5] Security for costs in special circumstances

heading.title: Security for costs in special circumstances

p.text: The requirement for special circumstances is consistent with the general rule that impecuniosity should not preclude a party from obtaining a proper adjudication of the merits of their claim or defence: Saba v National Australia Bank Ltd [1999] NSWCA 93; BC9901523 ; Bhattacharya v Freedman [2001] NSWSC 498; BC200103160 . Special circumstances have been found to exist:

where the appeal involves an apparent abuse of process: Weldon v Maples, Teesdale & Co (1887) 20 QBD 331 (But the exercise of the discretion to order security is not limited to appeals involving an apprehended abuse of process: Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2004] NSWCA 136; BC200401007 at [44] );
where the appeal is manifestly groundless: Lall v 53–55 Hall Street Pty Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 310 ;

where the appellant failed to contest the trial proceedings: Gray t/as Clarence Valley Plumbing v Ware Building Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 438; BC201210047 (failure to appear after application for adjournment dismissed);
where there is a risk the appeal will involve unnecessary costs: Lall v 53–55 Hall Street Pty Ltd , above (litigant in person);

where the appellant seeks to agitate almost all legal and factual issues raised at first instance: Ballard v Brookfield Australia Investments Ltd [2012] NSWCA 434; BC201210044 (security granted on a staged basis);

where there has been great delay in prosecuting the appeal: Smith v White [1879] WN (Eng) 203; Lydney and Wigpool Iron Ore Co v Bird (1883) 23 Ch D 358 ; PG Gabel Pty Ltd (in liq) v Katherine Enterprises Pty Ltd (1977) 29 FLR 108 at 113; (1977) 2 ACLR 400 ;
where there has been unexplained non-compliance with procedural directions and the appeal prospects were lacking in apparent substance: Levy v Bablis [2011] NSWCA 411; BC201110350 ;

where the appellant is a foreigner with few resources in Australia or elsewhere, whose general impecuniosity is of his own making, but who has otherwise been able to find resources of legal services to conduct litigation: Piras v Egan [2007] NSWCA 26; BC200700931 at [24]–[29] per Bryson JA; and

where the appellant’s costs are being met by a third party litigation funder: Green (in his capacity as liquidator of Arimco Mining Pty Ltd (in liq)) v CGU Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWCA 148; BC200804751 at [32] ; Winnote Pty Ltd (in liq) v Page (2005) 56 ACSR 35; [2005] NSWCA 362; BC200508998 at [23] ; Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2004) 208 ALR 564; [2004] NSWSC 664; BC200404777 at [81] .

The mere failure of an appellant to pay costs ordered against them in the court below is not, of itself, a special circumstance: Stevens v Economic House Builders Ltd [1938] 1 All ER 654. Such a failure may suggest an inability to pay the costs of a successful respondent and that inability, despite the general rule, has been held to constitute special circumstances: Kennedy v McGeechan [1978] 1 NSWLR 314 ; Abdurahman v Field (NSWSC, Kirby P, Glass and Samuels JJA, 4 March 1986, unreported, BC8601205); Citicorp Australia Ltd v Cirillo (2003) 228 LSJS 132; [2003] SASC 204; BC200303574 ; Kardynal v Dodek [1978] VR 414 ; Hills v London Passenger Transport Board [1937] 4 All ER 230; Horlock v Ashberry (1881) 19 Ch D 84 ; Hall v Snowdon & Co [1899] 1 QB 593 ; Bampton v Cook [1954] 1 All ER 457; [1954] 1 WLR 450; Wylde v Silver [1962] 2 All ER 809; [1962] 1 WLR 863 (assisted persons).

However, the importance of the general rule, and its emphasis by r 51.50(2), means that impecuniosity alone will not ordinarily constitute special circumstances so as to justify an order for security being made: Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd v Yolarno Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 136; BC200402460 ; Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw [2000] NSWCA 114; BC200002306 ; Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2004] NSWCA 69; BC200401007 at [44] ; Levy v Bablis [2011] NSWCA 411; BC201110350 . (It will rarely do so, for example, if the appellant's impecuniosity has been caused by the alleged misconduct of the respondent: Farrer v Lacy Hartland & Co (1885) 28 Ch D 482 at 485 .)

The court will take into account the appellant’s apparent prospects of success, the amount of the costs incurred (and likely to be incurred) as well as the amount of the security sought. A risk that ordering security may stultify an apparently meritorious appeal is a powerful consideration against ordering security: Bhattacharya v Freedman , above; Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd v Yolarno Pty Ltd , above; especially if the appeal involves a question of personal liberty: Kennedy v McGeechan , above. The fact that an appellant is impecunious does not of itself show that an appeal would be stultified if security were ordered: Hastings v Hastings [2009] NSWCA 294; BC200908694 at [14] (the possibility of financial assistance from third parties is a relevant consideration).

The requirement for “special circumstances” does not apply to applications for security in leave to appeal proceedings, to which the provisions of UCPR r 42.21 (the general provision dealing with security for costs), and the court’s incidental jurisdiction apply: Charara v Integrex Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 342; BC201009314 . But it will be a rare situation where any significant order would be made for security in leave to appeal proceedings: Charara v Integrex Pty Ltd, above (small appeal — absence of apparent prospects — modest order made).

level.toc-caption: [51.50.10] Corporate appellant

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.50.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1335.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.1(4).

Section 1335 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) authorises orders for security against corporate “plaintiffs” that are unlikely to be able to pay the costs of a successful defendant. UCPR r 51.1(4) treats a moving party in the Court of Appeal as a “plaintiff” for the purpose of the rules. Consequently, the view has consistently been taken that the Corporations Act permits security to be ordered against a corporate appellant: J & M O'Brien Enterprises Pty Ltd v Shell Co of Australia (1983) 70 FLR 261; (1983) 7 ACLR 790 and Chris Poulson Insurance Agencies Pty Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn (TASSC, Evans J, 17 July 1998, unreported, BC9803308); Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw [2000] NSWCA 114; BC200002306 ; Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw [2000] NSWCA 225; BC200004852 ; FPM Constructions Pty Ltd v Council of the City of Blue Mountains [2005] NSWCA 147; BC200502851 (Handley JA); Winnote Pty Ltd (in liq) v Page (2005) 64 NSWLR 244; 56 ACSR 35; [2005] NSWCA 362; BC200508998 at [23] — not following the contrary view expressed in Uptown Sydney Development Corp Pty Ltd v Bank of New Zealand (No 1) (1993) 11 ACSR 300; 11 ACLC 862; BC9303646 per Kirby P. Because of the provision in s 1335 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth), the power of the court to order security for the costs of an appeal brought by a corporation is not constrained by the requirement of “special circumstances”: Pioneer Park Pty Ltd (in liq) v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd [2007] NSWCA 344; BC200710441 at [22] per Basten JA, at [2] and [10] per Tobias and McColl JJA agreeing .

level.toc-caption: [51.50.15] Multiple appellants

p.text: If there are several appellants in the same interest, and grounds for security are made out against only some of them, it will not ordinarily be appropriate to order security against any of the appellants: Uptown Sydney Development Corp Pty Ltd v Bank of New Zealand (No 1) (1993) 11 ACSR 300; 11 ACLC 862; BC9303646 , see also [42.21.75] .

level.toc-caption: [51.50.20] Dismissal for failure to provide security

heading.title: Dismissal for failure to provide security

p.text: The court may dismiss an appeal where an appellant has failed to comply with an order to provide security for costs: Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd (No 3) [2005] NSWCA 377; BC200509277 and see [42.21.110] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.51] r 51.51 Additional evidence (cf SCR Part 51, rule 19)

p.text: This rule applies to an application to receive additional evidence.
The application must be made by motion returnable on the return day or, with leave of the Court, on a later day.
Part 18 makes provision with respect to motions and notices of motion.
The grounds must be stated in an affidavit.
Evidence necessary to establish the grounds of the application, and the evidence the applicant wants the Court to receive, must be given by affidavit.
The evidence of any party in response must be given by affidavit filed within the time directed by the Court.
A party must, not later than the time limited for filing an affidavit under this rule:
file as many copies of the affidavit as the Court may direct, and
serve 3 copies of the affidavit on each other interested party.

level.toc-caption: [51.51.5] Limitation on further evidence on appeal — SCA s 75A(8) and (9)

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.51.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A(5), s 75A(7)–(9).

heading.title: Limitation on further evidence on appeal — SCA s 75A(8) and (9)

p.text: An appeal to the Court of Appeal in civil proceedings is conducted by way of rehearing: see SCA s 75A(5) . The Court of Appeal may give any judgment, or make any order, the nature of the case requires. Moreover, s 75A(7)–(9) allow the court to receive further evidence on an appeal, although only on “special grounds” where: (i) the appeal follows a “hearing on the merits”; and (ii) the evidence relates to matters that occurred before the hearing. The breadth and nature of the powers so conferred is essentially a question of statutory construction, the answer to which may be informed, but not governed, by decisions on analogous common law powers: CDJ v VAJ (No 1) (1998) 197 CLR 172 at 197–8; 157 ALR 686; BC9805442 . Under common law procedures further evidence should generally not be admitted on an appeal, unless there is some “insistent demand of justice” that requires its admission: Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435 at 444; 29 ALJR 36 at 38; BC5500160 ; McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418; [1955] ALR 14; BC5400040 . In the exercise of the discretion conferred by s 75A(7)–(9), the common law procedures have a continuing, although not controlling, relevance because the section implicitly requires regard to be had to the essentially appellate function of the Court of Appeal: Doherty v Liverpool District Hospital (1991) 22 NSWLR 284 ; Radnedge v GIO (NSW) (1987) 9 NSWLR 235 ; to the general undesirability of permitting the admission of further evidence, and to the public interest in the finality of litigation: Mulholland v Mitchell [1971] AC 666; [1971] 1 All ER 307; [1971] 2 WLR 93 ; Warr v Santos [1973] 1 NSWLR 432 at 440 ; Radnedge v GIO (NSW) , above.

level.toc-caption: [51.51.10] Fresh evidence — matters occurring after hearing on merits

heading.title: Fresh evidence — matters occurring after hearing on merits

p.text: Where the further evidence relates to matters that occurred before the trial, SCA s 75A(8) directs the court shall not receive the evidence except on special grounds. It is impossible to provide an exhaustive statement about what constitutes special grounds: Re Chennell (1878) 8 Ch D 492 at 505 per Jessel MR and see Vasiljev v Public Trustee [1974] 2 NSWLR 497 ; Martin v Abbott Australasia Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 430 at 436 ; Murphy v Stone-Wallwork (Charlton) Ltd [1969] 2 All ER 949; [1969] 1 WLR 1023 at 1035 ; Mulholland v Mitchell [1971] AC 666 at 676, 679, 681; [1971] 1 All ER 307; [1971] 2 WLR 93 . Generally, the three conditions set out below have been regarded as the usual requirements it is necessary to satisfy in order to demonstrate that “special circumstances” exist : Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435 at 444; 29 ALJR 36 at 38; BC5500160 ; Preston v Green (1944) 61 WN (NSW) 204 ; Akins v National Australia Bank (1994) 34 NSWLR 155 at 160; BC9403049 . But this generality, whilst emphasising the potential importance of the three conditions, does not make any single matter a necessarily determinative criterion: Phoenix Commercial Enterprises Pty Ltd v City of Canada Bay Council [2010] NSWCA 64; BC201001880 esp at [13]–[22] per Spigelman CJ.

The proposed further evidence must be appropriately credible: Ladd v Marshall [1954] 3 All ER 745; [1954] 1 WLR 1489 ; Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632; 22 ALJR 283; BC4800240 ; McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418; [1955] ALR 14; BC5400040 ; Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435; 29 ALJR 36; BC5500160 ; McIntosh v Williams [1976] 2 NSWLR 237 ; Skone v Skone [1971] 2 All ER 582; [1971] 1 WLR 812 ; Roe v Robert McGregor & Sons Ltd [1968] 2 All ER 636; [1968] 1 WLR 925 .

The proposed evidence must gives rise to a high probability of a different judgment or order: CDJ v VAJ (No 1) (1998) 197 CLR 172; 157 ALR 686; BC9805442 at [111] ; Newington v Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd [2000] FCA 338; BC200001154 ; Hip Foong Hong v H Neotia & Co [1918] AC 888 at 894 ; R v Copestake [1927] 1 KB 468 at 474, 477; [1926] All ER Rep 252 ; Rowell v Pratt [1937] AC 116; Andrew v Andrew [1953] 1 WLR 1454; Akins v National Australia Bank (1994) 34 NSWLR 155; BC9403049 ; Commissioner for Govt Tram & Omnibus Services v Vickery (1952) 85 CLR 635 at 643; 26 ALJR 249; BC5200220 ; Braddock v Tillotsons Newspapers Ltd [1950] 1 KB 47; [1949] 2 All ER 306 (evidence relevant only in cross-examination as to credit — see also Meek v Fleming [1961] 2 QB 366; [1961] 3 All ER 148; [1961] 3 WLR 532 ); Tijong v Tijong [2012] NSWCA 201; BC201204951 at [171]–[174], [195]–[203] (findings in civil proceedings of perjury and forgery — further evidence not sufficiently probative).

heading.title: (iii) Not previously obtainable by reasonable diligence

p.text: The party seeking to rely on the additional evidence must ordinarily show that, even with the exercise of reasonable diligence, the evidence would not have been available for use at the trial: Shedden v Patrick (1869) LR 1 CL 470 at 545; Turnbull v Duval [1902] AC 429 (document obtainable on discovery); Technograph Printed Circuits Ltd v Mills and Rockley (Electronics) Ltd [1969] RPC 395 (surprise occasioned by the course of the trial); Glover v Australian Ultra Concrete Floors Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 80; BC200301878 (surprise during the course of the trial — corroborative further evidence admitted on appeal); Skone v Skone [1971] 2 All ER 582; [1971] 1 WLR 812 (possible deception by other party); Meek v Fleming [1961] 2 QB 366; [1961] 3 All ER 148; [1961] 3 WLR 532 (deception by a party); Nyerlucz v Dei Rocini (NSWCA, Mahoney AP, Clarke and Meagher JJA, 8 September 1995, unreported, BC9505311) (witness not approached before the trial because of reasonable apprehension of warning the opposing party of surveillance).

The requirement of pre-trial unavailability cannot be satisfied by a contention that legal representatives failed to rely upon, or obtain, relevant evidence: Hampson v Hampson [2010] NSWCA 359; BC201009847 at [33]–[38] per Campbell JA.

level.toc-caption: [51.51.15] Fresh evidence — matter occurring after trial

heading.title: Fresh evidence — matter occurring after trial

p.text: Where the further evidence relates to matters that have occurred after the trial there is no legislative prohibition restricting the use of further evidence on appeal to “special grounds”: see SCA s 75A(9); — except for the permissive reference in SCA s 106 to special circumstances in appeals after jury trials. But the general discretion is not at large and is to be exercised in accordance with principles developed in relation to similar rules (eg the former English Rules of Court): Doherty v Liverpool District Hospital (1991) 22 NSWLR 284 ; Radnedge v GIO (NSW) (1987) 9 NSWLR 235 . While it is not possible to specify any precise formula for the exercise of such a general discretion: Mulholland v Mitchell [1971] AC 666; [1971] 1 All ER 307; [1971] 2 WLR 93 ; regard should be had to the context in which the question arises, particularly the nature of the proceedings, and the general public interest in the finality of litigation: Doherty , above. The further evidence should not be admitted where it relates to contingencies that were taken into account (either expressly, or even implicitly) in the first instance judgment. Matters that fall into this category include:

evidence of the death of a party where life expectancy was an issue in the proceedings: Doherty , above, (death of plaintiff); CSR Ltd v Bouwhuis (NSWCA, Full Court, 23 August 1991, unreported, BC9101625) (shorter life expectancy);
evidence relating to future economic loss: Hogan v Taylor (NSWCA, 9 August 1982, unreported) (change in wage rates);
evidence relating to remarriage where the prospect of remarriage was an issue in the proceedings: Sinclair v Graham [1984] 2 NSWLR 253 (evidence of plaintiff's remarriage after hearing rejected).

Fresh evidence may be admitted where factual assumptions basic to the proceedings have been falsified by subsequent events: Barder v Caluori [1988] AC 20; [1987] 2 All ER 440; [1987] 2 WLR 1350; [1987] 2 FLR 480 (death of children and suicide by a former spouse after consent orders made in divorce proceedings); Murphy v Stone-Wallwork (Charlton) Ltd [1969] 2 All ER 949; [1969] 1 WLR 1023 (plaintiff dismissed by defendant employer contrary to assumption at trial): Jenkins v Livesey [1985] AC 424; [1985] 1 All ER 106 (leave granted where a party failed to disclose her intention to remarry and did remarry shortly after the orders were made). Vernon v Bosely [1998] 1 QB 18 (expert evidence given at trial contradicted by the same experts in subsequent proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [51.51.20] Fresh evidence — interlocutory appeals

p.text: Further evidence may be admitted on an appeal in an interlocutory matter: Clarke v Japan Machines (Aust) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 Qd R 404 ; Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corp Pty Ltd (No 4) (1986) 6 NSWLR 674 .

level.toc-caption: [51.51.25] Fresh evidence — where appeal otherwise succeeds

heading.title: Fresh evidence — where appeal otherwise succeeds

p.text: The limitations on the reception of further evidence on appeal apply with principal force where the further evidence is sought to be relied upon as a basis for one or more of the grounds of appeal. Different considerations may apply where the appeal succeeds on other grounds and where the matter for determination is the order that should be made, in particular whether the proceedings should be remitted for a new trial or whether the Court of Appeal should itself determine the matter: Tamas v Streimer (at [456,200] behind guide card “Practice Decisions” in vol 3). In Warr v Santos [1973] 1 NSWLR 432 evidence relating to matters that occurred after the trial was admitted where it was relevant to the assessment of damages after the appeal had been allowed on other grounds.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.52] r 51.52 Powers of Court on appeal not limited by certain procedural matters (cf SCR Part 51, rule 22)

leg:heading.title: Powers of Court on appeal not limited by certain procedural matters (cf SCR Part 51, rule 22)

p.text: The Court may exercise its powers under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 , the Supreme Court Act 1970 and these rules even if:
there is no appeal from some part of the decision below, or
a party to the proceedings below has not appealed, or
a ground for allowing or dismissing the appeal or varying the decision is not included in any notice of appeal, notice of cross-appeal or notice of contention, or
there has been no appeal from some other decision in the proceedings.

If a person was not a party to the proceedings in which the decision below was given, but is served with a notice of appeal pursuant to a direction of the Court, the Court may give such decision as might have been given in the court below if the person served had been a party below.
The Court may, on terms, make any order to ensure the determination on the merits of the real question in controversy.
The Court may make any order that it might make on an application for a new trial or for the setting aside of a verdict or judgment.
This rule applies subject to any Act.

level.toc-caption: [51.52.5] Powers of the Court of Appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.52.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 51.53, 51.54.

heading.title: Powers of the Court of Appeal

p.text: The present rule complements the provisions of SCA ss 75A, 102, 107 and 108. Reference should be made to those sections and their accompanying annotations as well as the annotations to UCPR 51.53 and 51.54 .

level.toc-caption: [51.52.10] Effect upon third parties

p.text: This rule permits the Court of Appeal to take into account the effect orders may have on the interests of persons other than the actual parties to the appeal, for examples see: Attorney-General v Simpson [1901] 2 Ch 671 ; Rutherford v Richardson [1922] P 144; [1923] AC 1 ; Re Whiston [1924] 1 Ch 122 and Hanson v Wearmouth Coal Co Ltd [1939] 3 All ER 47 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.53] r 51.53 Circumstances in which Court may order new trial (cf SCR Part 51, rule 23)

leg:heading.title: Circumstances in which Court may order new trial (cf SCR Part 51, rule 23)

p.text: The Court must not order a new trial on any of the following grounds:
misdirection, non-direction or other error of law,
improper admission or rejection of evidence,
that the verdict of the jury below was not taken on a question that the trial judge was not asked to leave to the jury,
on any other ground,
unless it appears to the Court that some substantial wrong or miscarriage has been thereby occasioned.
The Court may order a new trial on any question without interfering with the decision on any other question.

If it appears to the Court that some ground for a new trial affects part only of the matter in controversy, or one or some only of the parties, the Court may order a new trial as to that part only, or as to that party or those parties only.
If the Court makes an order under subrule (2) or (3), it may give such judgment or make such order as the nature of the case requires for the disposal of the remainder of the appeal.
If the Court orders a new trial, the Court may:
impose conditions on any party for the purposes of the new trial, and
direct admissions to be made by any party for the purpose of the new trial, and
order that the testimony of any witness examined at the former trial may be read from the transcript, instead of the witness being again examined.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.5] New trial — powers of the Court of Appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.53.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 102, s 75A.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 126.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.53, r 51.53(1).

heading.title: New trial — powers of the Court of Appeal

p.text: Applications for a new trial are made by way of appeal to the Court of Appeal: SCA s 102 (unless the proceedings are in the District Court and a timely application is made under DCA s 126 ). In such an appeal the powers of the Court of Appeal are generally governed by ss 102–108 — because SCA s 75A (which confers specific powers upon the Court of Appeal as to the drawing of inferences, the reception of further evidence and as to the making of any order which “ought to have been made” by the court below) does not apply to appeals arising out of a jury trial.

Where where SCA s 75A can apply to the appeal, the power SCA s 75A(10) confers (to make any finding or order the nature of the case requires) is regarded as qualified by UCPR r 51.53(1) . There has been inconclusive judicial discussion about whether the constraint imposed by UCPR r 51.53 is consistent with the breadth of the SCA s 75A(10) power and the relationship between those provisions is not entirely clear: see Mastronardi v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 54; BC200701760 at [72]–[85] , in particular [74] per Basten JA, Ipp and Campbell JJA agreeing; King v Collins [2007] NSWCA 122; BC200703977 at [8] per Basten JA, Mason P and Santow JA agreeing: see further [51.23.20] .

The requirement in UCPR r 51.53 that the court considers there has been a “substantial wrong or miscarriage” may be satisfied by the parties’ consent: Dean v Stockland Property Management Pty Ltd (No 2) [2010] NSWCA 141; BC201004114 at [38]–[41]. But if the court considers that the relevant error could not have affected the result, then the court is unlikely to be satisfied that there has been a “substantial wrong or miscarriage”: Tory v Megna [2007] NSWCA 13; BC200700728 at [28]–[30], [41] per Spigelman CJ, Beazley and Bryson JJA agreeing (no substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice on the facts); Nasr v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 101; BC200703257 at [25]–[27] per Campbell JA, Beazley and Hodgson JJA agreeing (no substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice on the facts).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.10] Substituted verdict

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.53.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 107.

SCA s 107 permits the Court of Appeal, where it would otherwise set aside a verdict and order a new trial, to substitute its own assessment for the amount awarded at the trial. Exercise of the power is subject to the Court of Appeal being satisfied that it is fully able to assess the amount of the debt or damages. The Court of Appeal cannot order a substituted verdict merely on the basis of its view of what the result of the trial might have been if the relevant error had not occurred: Balenzuela v De Gail (1959) 101 CLR 226; [1959] ALR 283; BC5900210 ; Bray v Ford [1896] AC 44 ; General Motors-Holdens Pty Ltd v Moularas (1964) 111 CLR 234; [1965] ALR 646; BC6400360 ; Nano v Der Hedde [1961] NSWR 818 ; Chatzipantelis v Grimwade Castings Pty Ltd [1966] VR 242 . See also Plumb v Australian Consolidated Press [1975] 2 NSWLR 415.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.15] New trial — orders limiting nature and scope

heading.title: New trial — orders limiting nature and scope

p.text: If a new trial is ordered, it may sometimes be appropriate to order the new trial be limited to particular issues involved in the appeal: Pateman v Higgin (1957) 97 CLR 521 at 527; [1957] ALR 996; BC5700550 (retrial on damages); Morgan v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (No 2) (1991) 23 NSWLR 374 (retrial limited to the defence of statutory qualified privilege): see [SCA s 108.5] ; but only if those issues, and those remitted, can properly be determined separately: CSR v Maddalena (2006) 224 ALR 1; [2006] HCA 1; BC200600188 at [76]–[87] (liability and damages issues related); Waterways Authority v Fitzgibbon (2005) 221 ALR 402; [2005] HCA 5; BC200507469 at [13]–[20] (factual issue not appropriate for separate determination).

It will not ordinarily be appropriate to direct that the re-trial be before a particular judge: Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden (No 2) (2003) 57 NSWLR 338; [2003] NSWCA 186; BC200303648 ; Holden v Wyong Shire Council (NSWCA, Full Court, No 314/85, 9 June 1988, unreported, BC8801849); cf Lockyer v Macready (1965) 66 SR (NSW) 369 at 382 ; Escobar v Spindaleri (1986) 7 NSWLR 51 at 58; (1986) 11 ALN N175 . But in particular circumstances, the Court of Appeal may direct that the lower court be differently constituted: Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (1992) 176 CLR 256 at 269; 108 ALR 55; BC9202693 (adverse credibility findings in the original decision); Steedman v Baulkham Hills Shire Council (No 2) (1993) 31 NSWLR 562 at 576; 80 LGERA 323; BC9304100 ; Seltsam Pty Ltd v Ghaleb (2005) 3 DDCR 1; [2005] NSWCA 208; BC200506381 at [12]–[14], [142], [235]–[239] (breach of procedural fairness); Castle Constructions Pty Ltd v North Sydney Council (2007) 155 LGERA 52; [2007] NSWCA 164; BC200706010 at [70]–[84] (reasonable apprehension of bias); Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co [2001] NSWCA 407; BC200107299 (appeal allowed on ground of trial judge’s bias); or that it be reconstituted by the same judicial officer: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Wang (2003) 196 ALR 385; 77 ALJR 786; [2003] HCA 11; BC200300805 ; Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden (No 2), above, at [39]–[42].

level.toc-caption: [51.53.20] New trial — substantial wrong or miscarriage

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.53.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.53, r 51.53(1).

heading.title: New trial — substantial wrong or miscarriage

p.text: Some doubts have been expressed about the validity and scope of predecessor of UCPR r 51.53(1) (SCR Pt 51 r 23(1) in similar form to the current rule) having regard to the amplitude of the power conferred by SCA s 75A(1): Whisprun Pty Ltd v Dixon (2003) 200 ALR 447; (2003) 77 ALJR 1598; BC200304981 at [113] per Kirby J in dissent; Gerlach v Clifton Bricks Pty Ltd (2002) 209 CLR 478; (2002) 188 ALR 353; BC200202747 at [53] per Kirby and Callinan JJ (not absolutely clear that the rule refers to orders for a new trial in the District Court); Seltsam Pty Ltd v Ghaleb [2005] NSWCA 208; BC200506381 at [167] (doubts as to the operation of the rule in relation to appeals under the Dust Diseases Act 1989 (NSW)).

These doubts are unlikely to have any significant practical consequence — because UCPR r 51.53 reflects common law principles and can properly co-exist with the principled exercise of the power conferred by SCA s 75A(10): Mastronardi v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 54; BC200701760 at [74]–[85] . The prohibition on the granting of a new trial, except in the case of substantial wrong or miscarriage, recognises the need for finality in litigation and the desirability of avoiding the hardship and cost that re-trial may cause: Balenzuela v De Gail (1959) 101 CLR 226; [1959] ALR 283; BC5900210 ; Hoyt's Pty Ltd v O'Connor (1928) 40 CLR 566 at 576; [1928] VLR 222; BC2800032 ; Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632 at 640; 22 ALJR 283; BC4800240 ; Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435 at 444; 29 ALJR 36 at 38; BC5500160 ; Dakhyl v Labouchere [1908] 2 KB 325n at 327; (1907) 77 LJKB 728 at 729 (retrial is a “deplorable” result of an appeal).

Consistent with this general principle, a new trial ought not to be ordered if the court is affirmatively satisfied that any error in the conduct of the proceedings did not really bear upon the result of the trial: Freeman v GJ Coles & Co Ltd [1967] 1 NSWR 297 (evidence admitted at trial but would not have affected the ultimate result — no new trial) (referred to with approval in Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [2002] NSWCA 419; BC200208153 at [93], [96] ; Tory v Megna [2007] NSWCA 13; BC200700728 ); Coroneo v Kurri Kurri & South Maitland Amusement Co Ltd (1934) 51 CLR 328 at 345; 34 SR (NSW) 444 (not sufficient merely to raise a doubt about the correctness of the first trial). However, the concept of substantial wrong or miscarriage includes a failure to observe the requirements of natural justice in the course of the proceedings: Stead v State Government Insurance Comm (1986) 161 CLR 141; 67 ALR 21; BC8601459 (acceptance of witnesses after foreshadowing rejection and truncating submissions); Peakhurst Inn Pty Ltd v Fox [2004] NSWCA 74; BC200401821 (adverse reliance on a point after telling parties it did not merit submissions); the inadequacy of the trial judge's reasons for judgment: Hadid v Redpath (2001) 35 MVR 152 at 164; [2001] NSWCA 416; BC200107191 (long delay); Dixon v Whisprun Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 344; BC200105898 (failure of judge to consider the extent to which the plaintiff's medical symptoms contributed to adverse credibility findings). In such cases it is not necessary to satisfy the court that the result of the trial was in fact affected by the error: Ashley v Schonberger [1968] VR 22 at 26 ; Holford v Melbourne Tramway & Omnibus Co Ltd [1909] VLR 497 at 527; (1907) 13 ALR 667 : Tory v Megna [2007] NSWCA 13; BC200700728 at [30]–[37] ; Mastronardi v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 54; BC200701760 at [74]–[85] ; and the court may order a retrial if it is satisfied that the error was capable of affecting the outcome of the proceedings: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141; (1986) 67 ALR 21; BC8601459 ; Mastronardi v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 54; BC200701760 at [83]–[87] .

The exercise of the power to order a re-trial presupposes that the court is not satisfied (after a non jury trial to which SCA s 75A(10) applies) that it is appropriate to make its own findings on the matters in question or (after a jury trial to which SCA s 107 applies) that it is “fully able” to make its own assessment or the parties consent to the proposed judgment: Selman v Minogue (1937) 37 SR (NSW) 280; 54 WN (NSW) 110 (jury trial — plaintiff consents to reduction in damages — retrial dispensed with). An alternative outcome, although one that presumably requires the consent of the parties, is to permit the parties to discharge the order for a retrial by accepting a judgment in a specified amount: Buckle v Hordern (1894) 11 WN (NSW) 70 (damages appeal — order for retrial — order to be discharged if the plaintiff accepted a specified amount).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.25] Evidence — appeal against wrongful rejection or admission

heading.title: Evidence — appeal against wrongful rejection or admission

p.text: Parties are entitled to have their cases dealt with on the basis the court or jury has considered only relevant and properly admissible evidence: Bray v Ford [1896] AC 44 at 49 . The improper admission or rejection of material evidence will form the basis for an order for a new trial if the court is satisfied that it has caused a substantial wrong or miscarriage. A new trial should not be ordered where the allegedly wrongful admission or rejection relates to immaterial evidence, nor where the wrongly rejected evidence could not support a verdict in favour of the appellant, nor where a verdict would be wrong in law: Hughes v Kirby (t/as Combined Petroleum Service) (NSWCA, Mahoney, Meagher and Handley JJA, 27 September 1991, unreported, BC9101530); Cross v Good (1887) 8 NSWLR 255; Walter v Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 251 at 260 ; Chatzipantelis v Grimwade Castings Pty Ltd [1966] VR 242 at 247 ; Deane v City Bank of Sydney (1904) 2 CLR 198; 11 ALR 1; BC0400011 ; Liddell v Harper (1874) 13 SCR (NSW) 129 ; Armstrong v Great Southern Gold Mining Co NL (1911) 12 CLR 382; [1912] VLR 61; BC1100028 . Where the only ground of objection to the admission of evidence is merely one of relevance, it is likely to be difficult to show that its admission occasioned a substantial wrong or miscarriage: Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442; 23 ALJR 508; BC4900470 ; Speirs v Caledonian Collieries Ltd (1957) SR (NSW) 483 ; Caledonian Collieries Ltd v Speirs (1957) 97 CLR 202; 31 ALJR 132; BC5700360 ; Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298; [1959] ALR 367; BC5900240 ; Piddington v Bennett and Wood Pty Ltd (1940) 63 CLR 533 at 554, 560; 13 ALJR 512 ; Nominal Defendant v Clements (1960) 104 CLR 476 at 496; [1960] ALR 701; BC6000700 ; Balenzuela v De Gail (1959) 101 CLR 226 at 242; [1959] ALR 283; BC5900210 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.30] Misdirection by the trial judge

p.text: Misdirection by the trial judge, on either matters of law or fact, can provide a basis for a new trial: Bright v Sampson & Duncan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 346 . A new trial may also be ordered if the trial judge's summing up is inadequate, even if it does not contain an express error: General Motors-Holdens Pty Ltd v Moularas (1964) 111 CLR 234 at 256; [1965] ALR 646; BC6400360 ; Hobbs v Tinling [1929] 2 KB 1 ; Cooper v Swadling [1930] 1 KB 403 . In either case, a new trial may only be ordered if the court is satisfied the error has caused a substantial wrong or miscarriage. That criterion requires a decision as to whether the misdirection, or non-direction, may have affected the result of the case: Balenzuela v De Gail (1959) 101 CLR 226 at 234–5; [1959] ALR 283; BC5900210 , per Dixon CJ; General Motors-Holdens, above, CLR at 253; Holford v Melbourne Tramway & Omnibus Co Ltd [1909] VLR 497 at 526; (1907) 13 ALR 667 . In order to make that decision the summing up must be considered as a whole: Jones v Canadian Pacific Railway (1914) 83 LJPC 20; Blue & Deschamps v Red Mountain Railway Co [1909] AC 361 . A distinction may be drawn between a misdirection on a matter of law and a misdirection that relates to matters of fact, including a direction relating to the significance of particular evidence. In the former case the criterion of substantial wrong or miscarriage may be more readily met, because each party is entitled to have the jury properly instructed on the relevant law: Steele v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 348 ; Payne v Parker [1976] 1 NSWLR 191 at 201D . In the case of an alleged misdirection on a matter of fact, it is necessary to remember that a trial judge is entitled to express views on matters of fact, and to do so forcefully, provided in the end result the directions as a whole make it clear the jury, and not the judge, is the ultimate arbiter on all factual questions: Holford, above, VLR at 520; Hocking v Bell (1945) 71 CLR 430 at 499; 46 SR (NSW) 251 ; Balenzuela v De Gail, above CLR at 236, 243; Smith v Dart (1884) 14 QBD 108; see also Hoger v Ellas [1963] NSWR 1033 at 1042 ; Murray v Wilson [1962] NSWR 1155 at 1160 ; Bugg v Day (1949) 79 CLR 442 at 455, 461–2; 23 ALJR 508; BC4900470 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.35] Misdirection by trial judge — failure to complain about at trial

heading.title: Misdirection by trial judge — failure to complain about at trial

p.text: Complaints about the summing up should be made at the trial. The objection should be specific and advocates should formulate the particular direction for which they contend: Singleton v Ffrench (1986) 5 NSWLR 425 at 440 . Failure to object at the trial is relevant to the discretion to order a new trial on the ground of misdirection: Calin v Greater Union Organisation Pty Ltd (1991) 173 CLR 33 at 39; 100 ALR 746; BC9102620 ; and may justify refusing to order a new trial if the failure to object implied consent to the matter being put to the jury in a particular way: Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 at 659–64 ; General Motors-Holdens Pty Ltd v Moularas (1964) 111 CLR 234 at 243; [1965] ALR 646; BC6400360 ; Burchett v Kane [1980] 2 NSWLR 266 at 277; Eggins v Brooms Head Bowling & Recreational Club Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 521; (1986) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-044 ; Morawski v State Rail Authority (NSW) (1988) 14 NSWLR 374 at 381 . However, the question whether an alleged misdirection can be raised on appeal, notwithstanding a failure to object at the trial, depends upon the requirements of justice in the particular circumstances of the case, rather than on the application of any inflexible rule: Calin v Greater Union Organisation Pty Ltd (1991) 173 CLR 33 at 39; 100 ALR 746; BC9102620 (failure to seek direction on alternative cause of action — no substantial injustice — appeal dismissed); Gipp v R (1998) 194 CLR 106; 155 ALR 15; [1998] HCA 21; BC9802404 (failure to direct on inconsistent and uncorroborated evidence — manifest injustice — appeal dismissed); Burston v Melbourne & Metropolitan Tramways Board (1948) 78 CLR 143 at 167; [1949] ALR 221 at 233; BC4800020 (direction adequate — appeal dismissed); Bright v Sampson & Duncan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 346 (unchallenged misdirection about the effect of evidence — substantial miscarriage — new trial ordered); Holford v Melbourne Tramway & Omnibus Co Ltd [1909] VLR 497; (1907) 13 ALR 667 (misdirection concerning credibility evidence — new trial ordered); Midalco Pty Ltd v Rabenalt [1989] VR 461; (1988) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-208 (misdirection unlikely to influence result — appeal dismissed).See further [51.53.105]–[51.53.130] .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.40] Misdirection by trial judge — explanation of failure to complain at trial

heading.title: Misdirection by trial judge — explanation of failure to complain at trial

p.text: The authorities referred to in the preceding paragraph establish that a failure to object can, but will not necessarily, provide a sufficient basis for refusing a new trial. The appropriate exercise of the discretion whether to allow that point to be raised depends upon the circumstances of the case. Of those circumstances, the way in which the trial was conducted and, in particular, whether the failure to object was a tactical decision made at the trial, can be a decisive consideration. For that reason, the court should be told why no objection was taken. If the explanation is contentious, it should be the subject of evidence before the Court of Appeal. Any affidavit of explanation should be served in sufficient time before the hearing to allow the respondent an opportunity to answer with its own evidence and to decide whether cross-examination is required: Lutwyche v Jiweni Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 27 May 1998 unreported, BC9803438); R v Hines (1991) 24 NSWLR 737 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.45] Misdirection complaint involving matter not raised at trial

heading.title: Misdirection complaint involving matter not raised at trial

p.text: The limitation against raising new matters on an appeal has particular emphasis when the matter sought to be raised involves an alleged misdirection in jury trials: Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 at 659–64 (deliberate failure to raise a point of law); General Motors-Holdens Pty Ltd v Moularas (1964) 111 CLR 234; [1965] ALR 646; BC6400360 (failure to require redirection); Jones v Dunkel (1959) 101 CLR 298 at 315; [1959] ALR 367; BC5900240 ; Burchett v Kane [1980] 2 NSWLR 266 (failure to object to direction); MacDougall v Knight (1889) 14 App Cas 194 ; Seaton v Burnand [1900] AC 135 at 143 : see also [51.53.30] .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.50] Natural justice — failure to afford party

heading.title: Natural justice — failure to afford party

p.text: Failure to afford natural justice to one or other of the parties may provide a separate ground of appeal. Ordinarily such a failure will justify an order for a new trial, unless the appeal court is satisfied the outcome of the proceedings could not have been affected by the failure: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141; 67 ALR 21; BC8601459 . Natural justice imposes a number of related requirements in connection with the fair and just disposition of the proceedings. These include providing the parties with:
a reasonable opportunity to adduce and test relevant evidence;
a reasonable opportunity to advance relevant submissions; and
proper and impartial evaluation of the evidence and submissions.

heading.title: Reasonable opportunity to adduce and test evidence

p.text: The trial judge should conduct the proceedings fairly and impartially. That will involve affording all parties an appropriate opportunity to present their evidence and submissions. The judge should not participate unduly either in the presentation of the evidence or in the arguments presented by the parties: Jones v National Coal Board [1957] 2 QB 55; [1957] 2 All ER 155 ; Yuill v Yuill [1945] P 15; [1945] 1 All ER 183 ; Tousek v Bernat (1959) 61 SR (NSW) 203 at 209; 77 WN (NSW) 838. If a judge interferes unduly in the conduct of the trial, or manifests an excessively disparaging, intemperate or critical attitude towards a party, that conduct may provide grounds for a new trial: Holt v Protective Cmr (1993) 31 NSWLR 227 ; Hughes v Kirby (t/as Combined Petroleum Service) (NSWCA, Mahoney, Meagher and Handley JJA, 27 September 1991, unreported, BC9101530); Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co [2001] NSWCA 407; BC200107299 at [78]–[98], [111], [156] (judge engaging in provocative, sarcastic and harassing conduct towards a party’s non-professional representative).

heading.title: Reasonable opportunity to advance relevant submissions

p.text: A judge must afford both parties a reasonable opportunity to advance relevant submissions. It will ordinarily, therefore, be wrong to find against a party after either refusing to hear, or dispensing with, that parties’ submissions on a particular point: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141; 67 ALR 21; BC8601459 (adverse reliance on a witness after dispensing with contrary submissions); Peakhurst Inn Pty Ltd v Fox [2004] NSWCA 74; BC200401821 (adverse reliance on a point after telling parties it did not merit submissions). Similarly, a judge must confine themselves to matters that are formally and properly evidence in the proceedings or in relation to which the parties have been given proper notice: Simmonds v Spooner (No 3) (NSWCA, Kirby, Cole and Rolfe JJ, 40738 of 1990, 28 March 1995, unreported, BC9504437) (reliance upon affidavit material not read at the hearing of the proceedings).

heading.title: Proper and impartial evaluation of evidence and submissions

p.text: The public interest in the proper administration of the judicial process imposes necessarily high standards of attention, timeliness courtesy, restraint and “disinterestedness”: Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co [2001] NSWCA 407; BC200107299 at [159]–[165] . Those standards relate to both the actuality and the appearance of the trial process — what is sometimes referred to as both “outcome” and “process”. They require a judge’s conscientious attention to the conduct of the proceedings: Cesan v R (2008) 250 ALR 192; [2008] HCA 52; BC200809727 at [64]–[89] (judge repeatedly asleep during jury trial). They also require timely delivery of reasons and judgment after the trial process: see [36.2.25] . The requirement of proper attention may involve directing the parties to difficulties that emerge during the course of the proceedings — a judge’s obligation of impartial evaluation is not discharged by mere silence during a trial: Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 ; Vakauta v Kelly (1989) 167 CLR 568; 87 ALR 633; BC8902709 . Whether the complaint is about the judge’s inattention, silence or apparent partiality, the critical question is whether, by reason of the judge’s conduct of the proceedings, there has been a real danger the trial was unfair: Galea v Galea (1990) 19 NSWLR 263 at 281 ; EH Cochrane Ltd v Ministry of Transport [1987] 1 NZLR 146; (1987) 3 CRNZ 38 . In addressing that question, in response to a complaint of apparent partiality, a distinction is to be drawn between comments made by a judge for the purpose of indicating provisional views — and inviting argument in relation to them — and comments suggesting the formation of an opinion that will not be altered by either evidence or argument: Marriage of Lonard (1976) 11 ALR 618; (1976) 26 FLR 1 at 10 ; cf Re Hornby; Ex parte Prentice [1970] 1 NSWR 654; (1970) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 427 ; Galea , above, at 281.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.55] Trial judge — bias of

p.text: It is a fundamental rule that every judicial tribunal must be, and be seen to be, impartial: Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488 at 501; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 : R v Sussex Justices Ex parte McCarthy [1924] 1 KB 256 (“justice should not only be done, but should manifestly and undoubtedly be seen to be done”). A material direct personal interest in the outcome of litigation gives rise to an automatic presumption of disqualifying bias — irrespective of evidence of the judge’s actual knowledge of that interest: Locabail (UK) Ltd v Bayfield Properties Ltd [2000] QB 451; [2000] 1 All ER 65; [2000] 2 WLR 870 . Even in the absence of direct personal interest, a judge ought not hear a case if a fair minded lay observer might reasonably apprehend an impartial judicial mind might not be brought to bear on the resolution of the proceedings: R v Watson; Ex parte Armstrong (1976) 136 CLR 248 at 265; 9 ALR 551; BC7600059 ; Livesey v New South Wales Bar Assn (1983) 151 CLR 288; 47 ALR 45; BC8300078 ; Vakauta v Kelly (1989) 167 CLR 568; 87 ALR 633; BC8902709 ; S & M Motor Repairs Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 358; 11 IPR 97 ; Re JRL; Ex parte CJL (1986) 161 CLR 342; 66 ALR 239; BC8601444 ; Metropolitan Properties Co (FGC) Ltd v Lannon [1969] 1 QB 577 at 599; [1968] 3 All ER 304; [1968] 3 WLR 694 .

Parties may waive any objection to the tribunal’s actual or apprehended partiality: Dovade Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Group (1999) 46 NSWLR 168; BC9901997 ; Vakauta v Kelly (1989) 167 CLR 568 at 572 and 577–9; 87 ALR 633; BC8902709 ; Smits v Roach (2004) 60 NSWLR 711; [2004] NSWCA 233; BC200404415 ; Locabail (UK) Ltd v Bayfield Properties Ltd , above. Waiver may be inferred from the deliberate absence of objection: Smits v Roach (2006) 227 CLR 423; 228 ALR 262; [2006] HCA 36; BC200605512 at [43], [61], [125] (judge’s brother known to be senior partner in firm where defendant worked); Battenberg v Union Club [2007] NSWSC 265; BC200701986 at [23], [24] , above; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Reid [2005] FCA 1274; BC200506817 at [115]–[117] (respondent claimed that judge should disqualify himself only after the completion of evidence and was aware from the outset claimed to give rise to apprehended bias).

A further qualification arises where necessity dictates that a particular judge must determine the issue. This kind of necessity may arise where there is no other judge or where there is no other judge free of the appearance of bias: see Ebner v Official Trustee in Bankruptcy (2000) 205 CLR 337; 176 ALR 644; BC200007446 at [6] (qualification of necessity may be relevant to second appeal).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.60] Reasonable apprehension of bias

p.text: The authorities emphasise that any “reasonable apprehension of bias” must be “firmly established” before it is appropriate for a judge to disqualify themselves from participating in the proceedings. The question of the hypothetical observer’s reasonable apprehension falls to be decided against the standards of ordinary judicial practice. Consider the following examples:
Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488 at 493, 508; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 (judge’s statement that he would not principally rely on the evidence of certain witnesses — no bias);

Ebner v Official Trustee in Bankruptcy (2000) 205 CLR 337 at 344, 365; 176 ALR 644; [2000] HCA 63; BC200007446 (disclosure of small shareholding in bank — post hearing inheritance of further shares not disclosed — no bias);
Dovade Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Group (1999) 46 NSWLR 168; 150 FLR 336; [1999] NSWCA 113; BC9901997 (judge’s wife a shareholder in bank — no bias);
Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Reid [2005] FCA 1274; BC200506817 (knowledge of prior contempt orders made by another judge and issue of a warrant to secure attendance — no bias;

In deciding the question of “reasonable apprehension” it is important judicial officers discharge their duty to sit, and do not accede too readily to suggestions of the appearance of bias. The issue in each case is whether there is a reasonable apprehension that the judge appointed to hear the matter might not bring an impartial and unprejudiced mind to its resolution: Aussie Airlines Pty Ltd v Australian Airlines Pty Ltd (1996) 65 FCR 215 at 230; 135 ALR 753; BC9600688 . A necessary corollary of this criterion is that a judge ought not to disqualify themselves except for proper reason: Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Tectran Corporation Pty Ltd (1986) 6 NSWLR 272; BC8600683 . The criterion of “reasonable apprehension” of bias should not be subverted into a lesser enquiry as to whether it would be “better” for another judge to hear the case. Applying such an imprecise and impressionistic criterion could encourage a belief that a party can, by making disqualification applications, obtain a hearing before a judge thought more likely to be favourable: Re JRL; Ex parte CJL (1986) 161 CLR 342 at 352; 66 ALR 239; 10 Fam LR 917; BC8601444 .

Neither an expectation about the way the judge is likely to decide the case, nor an express allegation of bias, is necessarily sufficient to generate a reasonable apprehension of partiality: Re JRL; Ex parte CJL (1986) 161 CLR 342 at 352; 66 ALR 239; 10 Fam LR 917; BC8601444 per Mason CJ. Similarly, the mere fact that a judge may have been informed of irrelevant or inadmissible material is insufficient to establish a reasonable apprehension of bias: Gas & Fuel Corporation Superannuation Fund v Saunders (1994) 52 FCR 48; 123 ALR 323; BC9406473 .

The assessment of reasonable apprehension is to be conducted on the basis of an assumption that the fair minded lay observer knows all the relevant circumstances: Vakauta v Kelly (1988) 13 NSWLR 502 at 528, 535–6; 8 MVR 54 . This includes knowledge of any circumstances that occurred after the contentious conduct, and permits regard to be had to the cumulative effect of the totality of the circumstances: Hamod v NSW [2011] NSWCA 375; BC201110561 at [259] per Beazley JA; Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 at [11]–[14] .

If the totality of the circumstances otherwise gives rise to a reasonable apprehension of bias, neither the judge’s own reasons for refusing to disqualify themselves, or their declarations of their intention to approach the proceedings with an open mind are relevant considerations: British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Laurie (2011) 242 CLR 283; 273 ALR 429; [2011] HCA 2; BC201100308 at [46], [80]–[81] and [132] (definitely expressed views made at an interlocutory stage of unrelated proceedings — apparently firm conviction of fraudulent conduct by common party — apparent bias).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.65] Bias arising from prior determinations

p.text: This limitation of reasonableness is particularly important in deciding whether a judge’s prior determinations indicate relevant bias. The question may arise as a result of (i) decisions made in other proceedings between the same parties, (ii) decisions in similar proceedings involving at least one of the parties, (iii) interlocutory decision in the proceedings (iv) observations made in the course of the hearing or (v) the determination of ancillary issues after the determination of the substantive issues in the proceedings. In all of these instances the “reasonable apprehension” criterion applies.

A reasonable apprehension of bias may arise where the judge has previously determined similar issues between the same parties: Australian National Industries Ltd v Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) (1992) 26 NSWLR 411; 9 ACSR 309 (successive trials involving related issues of fact and credit); Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co [2001] NSWCA 407; BC200107299 at [51], [75] (matters being heard together — judge determining one matter on the basis of an adverse credit finding prior to the close of evidence in the other matters).

A reasonable apprehension of bias may also arise where a judge determined similar issues in other proceedings involving the applicant party — at least if that decision involved firm, though temperate, findings of dishonesty or relevant impropriety: British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Laurie (2011) 242 CLR 283; 273 ALR 429; [2011] HCA 2; BC201100308 (inadequate discovery in prior proceedings — findings of dishonest fraudulent practices relevant to retention of relevant documents — proceedings involving similar claims — reasonable apprehension of bias).

Generally speaking, interlocutory rulings ought not be regarded as giving rise to a reasonable apprehension of bias unless they indicate a significant level of pre-judgment in relation to matters relevant to the final resolution of the proceedings: Laws v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1990) 170 CLR 70 at 100; 93 ALR 435; 64 ALJR 412; BC9002913 ; R v Masters (1992) 26 NSWLR 450 at 471; 59 A Crim R 445 . The same general approach applies to rulings and expressions of opinion made during the course of the proceedings: Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 ) (unlikelihood of accepting the uncorroborated evidence of either party — no reasonable apprehension of bias); Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2004] NSWSC 970; BC200407581 (evidentiary rulings involving disallowance of cross- examination — no reasonable apprehension of bias.

But this general approach must be applied to the particular circumstances. There are instances where the determination of issues at an interlocutory stage of proceedings can give rise to reasonable apprehensions of bias. This may occur, for example, where a judge has made adverse credibility findings in rejecting a claim for client legal privilege: Kwan v Kang [2003] NSWCA 336; BC200307596 at [71]–[75]; Nicholls v Michael Wilson & Partners Ltd (2010) 243 FLR 177; [2010] NSWCA 222; BC201006780 ; Southern Equities Corp Ltd (in liq) v Bond (2000) 78 SASR 339; 211 LSJS 487; [2000] SASC 450; BC200008099 (ruling on Mareva application — bias). Conversely, the mere fact that the judge has made various orders in the absence of a party, and prohibited disclosure to that party of both the applications and the orders, is not sufficient to indicate apparent bias if the matters addressed in the applications do not directly involve the issues in the proceedings or the assessment of the credibility of witnesses: Michael Wilson & Partners Ltd v Nicholls (2011) 282 ALR 685; 86 ALJR 14; [2011] HCA 48; BC201109206 (overruling Nicholls v Michael Wilson & Partners Ltd (2010) 243 FLR 177; [2010] NSWCA 222; BC201006780 ). If the application is based on the combined effect of a judge’s rulings on a range of different matters, the reasonableness of any apprehension of bias must be assessed by having regard to the matters impugned both individually and collectively: Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 .

Ancillary issues determined after the substantive hearing of the proceedings are comparatively unlikely to give rise to any reasonable apprehension of bias: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2004] NSWSC 270; BC200402171 (application for costs after trial proceedings stayed — no bias); Phillips v Symes (No 2) [2005] 4 All ER 519; [2005] 1 WLR 2043; [2005] 2 All ER (Comm) 538 (application for costs order against an expert witness whose evidence had been rejected — no bias); Bahai v Rashidian [1985] 3 All ER 385 at 388, 391; [1985] 1 WLR 1337 (costs application against party’s solicitor criticised in substantive judgment — no bias); Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2004] NSWSC 270; BC200402171 (defendant’s application for gross sum costs order following plaintiff’s failure to comply with order to provide security for costs — no bias).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.70] Bias — apprehension from prior professional relationship

heading.title: Bias — apprehension from prior professional relationship

p.text: A prior professional relationship between a judge and a former client is not sufficient in itself to disqualify the judge from sitting in proceedings to which the former client is a party: British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2007] NSWSC 109; BC200700912 (judge had previously acted for BATAS in previous proceedings claimed to involve substantially similar issues — not disqualified); Aussie Airlines Pty Ltd v Australian Airlines Pty Ltd (1996) 65 FCR 215 at 222; BC9600688 . The question of reasonable apprehended bias must be considered in the context of the issues that the court has to decide: British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2007] NSWSC 109; BC200700912 at [97], [114] . A reasonable apprehension of bias will only arise if the judge is likely to have had access to additional relevant (or privileged) material or is likely to have prejudged the issue for determination, or has some personal interest in adhering to previous advice: British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2007] NSWSC 109; BC200700912 .

In determining the reasonableness of any apprehended bias the judge must attribute to the hypothetical observer a reasonable understanding of the way in which judges, barristers and solicitors work: Aussie Airlines Pty Ltd v Australian Airlines Pty Ltd (1996) 65 FCR 215; BC9600688 (when barristers act for a client they do so in a professional capacity and could as easily have been briefed to fulfil the same task for the opposite side). In the application of these principles it is relatively uncommon for a judge’s prior professional association with a litigant to provide a basis for the judge’s disqualification on the ground of apprehended bias: S&M Motors Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 358; (1988) 91 FLR 175; (1988) 11 IPR 97 (long professional relationship between the judge and Caltex — no advice or representation on issues arising in instant case — not disqualified); Kartinyeri v Commonwealth (1998) 156 ALR 300; [1998] HCA 52 ; BC9804130 (hearing concerning constitutional validity of an Act — judge had previously provided an opinion to Senate Legal & Constitutional Affairs Committee on validity — not disqualified); Gascor (t/as Gas & Fuel) v Ellicott [1997] 1 VR 332; BC9601364 (arbitrator previously leading counsel for producers in arbitration on similar issues — not removed); Battenberg v Union Club [2007] NSWSC 265; BC200701986 at [24]–[25] (judge — then counsel — known to have advised defendant 4 years prior to proceedings — no bias); S&R Investments Pty Ltd v Minister for Planning [2001] WASC 255; BC200105625 (land acquisition compensation claim — settlement of earlier claim where judge had been counsel was important comparable transaction — judge disqualified himself).
